title: SatoPrincess
author: SatoPrincess
content: QuoteZenith Bank has written a two-page letter to one of its customers who watched over N4 million vanish from her account in 20minutes. The tier-one bank insisted that there was little they could do and offered to help her recover a small percentage if she obtained a court judgment. The missing money went viral on Tuesday, 13 January 2023 with the victim captured in a video crying at the banking hall.The Nigerian banking sector is awash with stories of similar incidents with many unresolved. As at December 2021, Punch reports that only four top banks recorded a total of 477,405 unresolved customer complaints and most are related to fraud. The banks are Zenith, Guaranty Trust Bank, United Bank for Africa, and Access Bank. The reports also revealed that the number of unresolved complaints carried forward by the banks in 2021 grew by 172,399 from 305,791 recorded in December 2020. For Zenith bank, a total of 166,314 complaints remained unresolved as of December 2021. This figure is almost double the amount recorded in 2021 (83,899).https://www.legit.ng/business-economy/money/1514076-court-zenith-replies-customer-cried-missing-n4m-account-pages-letter/ The banking sector is failing us, more than we know it. You go to any bank on a Monday, you will see a long queue of people with complaints at the customer care section. Everyone here has had one problem with bank transactions regardless of what bank you use. It’s sad to know that there is no reliable bank, crypto is the safest solution to this problem. You don’t have to buy bitcoin, you can use the money to buy stable coins and hodl them in a non custodial wallet. It’s like a fixed deposit account only better because you’re the only one that controls it. And you keep the rest of your money that will be used for daily expenses and business expenditures. Imo storing all your money in the bank is a bad idea. What happened to this lady could happen to you.

comments.author: Davidvictorson
comments.body: I can imagine the pain that young lady is passing through currently. I fear Nigerian Banks. I dread going to the banks. Whenever, I want to withdraw at an ATM or a POS I was say a silent prayer never to have a debit alert after a transaction declined notification or any other issue. Nigerian Banks have given me PTSD. So many persons have lost money to them and truth is, this is not a matter of having your funds in crypto. Other countries where these sorts of issues are resolved without stress didn't fall from the sky. I know we will get it right. But before we do, have more than one plan financial plan so that you don't trend on Social Media.

comments.author: sokani
comments.body: The issue of disappearing funds in bank accounts are increasing everyday. We should be careful of the links we click, the sensitive information we give out, and the people that have access to our phones/cards because that's some of the ways these fraudsters get access to our accounts. And I totally agree with you that it's not good to have all of one's eggs in one basket, it would be wise to have some savings in crypto because of the security challenges of the financial sector.

comments.author: Dr.Bitcoin_Strange
comments.body: Quote from: SatoPrincess on January 14, 2023, 09:09:37 AMThe banking sector is failing us, more than we know it. You go to any bank on a Monday, you will see a long queue of people with complaints at the customer care section.More of this type of incident will occur frequently in the future unless banks improve their security. The day I thought of this incident that is happening in the bank, I came up with a suggestion: banks should set up a facial recognition, SMS, and email verification system that customers must pass before spending a certain amount. a security measure to further verify the identity of the account holder before spending large amounts. Let's not be surprised that one day the press will release a report telling us that most of these bank fraudulent activities are being pioneered by some bank staff; that's just the risk of trusting our money with third parties. And the worst part of this is that after losing money in your bank account, if you visit the bank, they tell you to start some legal proceedings that will even require you to pay some money, while your money has just been stolen under their custody.Quote from: Igebotz on January 17, 2023, 09:36:33 PMif you give out your sensitive information to scammers, the banks cannot help much, but if it is due to bank-related system errors, you will always get your money back;  From what Igebotz said here, he's correct, but you can imagine how long it will take to get that money back with the long delays in the banking system these days. What if it's not that individual's money? What if the money was for a contract job? The thing is, all this is no longer funny; let the bank look for a proper solution. They can as well enable a security that allows people to freeze their money so that only the individual will be able to unfreeze it through some security means when ever they wish to spend some cash.Quote from: Merit.s on January 16, 2023, 09:25:04 PMsnipMahn, it's not only Nigerian banks; NAB also have some reports concerning fraudulent issues. Banks will not fail in 20 years like you said because you will still need them to spend your local currency, and digital money is not yet accepted by the mass..There is also no 100% security in holding your money in Bitcoin because you could also get hacked or lose your password or mistakenly release your phrase to a wrong hand.

Imo storing all your money in the bank is a bad idea. What happened to this lady could happen to you.Security is paramount whether purchasing cryptocurrency or paying with cash. If a person cannot safeguard his 4-digit bank pin from fraudsters, how can he safeguard his 12-digit seed phrase? An individual who is negligent with their sensitive information runs a significant danger of losing assets. And by the way, if you want to hold something for a very long time, you should go with bitcoin, it has high volatility but is the best option for long-term hodl. If you must hold a stablecoin, make sure it's a decentralized one that's pegged to the real value of the dollar. Even though USDT is excellent, I won't suggest it.
